content: The "Supporting Academic Freedom through Regulatory Relief Act" may be cited as the short title. It provides regulatory relief. The "Supporting Academic Freedom through Regulatory Relief Act" repeals certain regulations related to State authorization and the definition of credit hour in the Code of Federal Regulations. The "Supporting Academic Freedom through Regulatory Relief Act" repeals regulations related to gainful employment and sections of the Code of Federal Regulations published by the Department of Education in 2010 and 2011. The "Supporting Academic Freedom through Regulatory Relief Act" repeals regulations related to gainful employment and sections of the Code of Federal Regulations published by the Department of Education in 2010 and 2011. The Act restores and revives regulations that were amended on June 30, 2011, prohibiting the Secretary of Education from promulgating or enforcing new regulations regarding State authorization for institutions of higher education. The Act repeals regulations on gainful employment and State authorization for higher education institutions. It prohibits the Secretary of Education from enforcing new regulations on gainful employment and credit hours. The Act prohibits the Secretary of Education from enforcing regulations on the definition of the term "credit hour" under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Act prohibits the Secretary of Education from enforcing regulations on the definition of the term "credit hour" under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Additionally, the Act addresses third-party service providers. Section 487(a)(20) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow institutions to pay third-party entities for student recruitment services, under certain conditions. The Act also prohibits the Secretary of Education from regulating the definition of "credit hour" and addresses compensation restrictions for third-party service providers. The Higher Education Act of 1965 allows institutions to pay third-party entities for student recruitment services, with conditions such as not paying solely for recruitment services and ensuring student information is not shared or sold to other entities.
